66004.name: Archangels: In the Beginning
66004.description:
From the publisher:

In the beginning, God created the Heavens and the Earth.

Just before that, though, a very interesting argument had just ended.

Different aspects of the mind of God had incarnated long before the start of time, with the intention of making their opinions heard. Gabriel, Michael and Uriel formed a power block and refused to give up on the concept of determinism. Samael favored free will, and wanted a democratic decision made about it, but Phanuel refused them all point blank, saying that as the Face of God, He/She/It had to have the last say. Israfil tried to set Himself up as mediator (as usual), but was distracted as Raphael and Haniel almost came to blows over whether humanity should experience pain. Only Azrael, the Angel of Death, stayed out of it. As It watched the ensuing threats and complaints, It found Itself shaking Its head. With the entirety of creation at stake, a metaphysical argument could cause a fall from grace for eternity. It would be a miracle if they got it all started without killing themselves.

Looking at the universe we got, who said it was not created by a committee?

Archangels : In the Beginning is a Freeform LARP (Live Action Role Play) event game using A Token System, set at the dawn of time for sixteen parts of the mind of God. I wrote this game after an overdose of Vampire, Cthulhu and ghost games, and wanted to see life on the Other Side. Divine power, infinite possibility, boundless ego. Does that spell trouble? You betcha. Knowledge of any gaming system is unessential, and in fact may give headaches.

66005.name: The Labourer
66005.description:
From the publisher:

The Labourer
One of the Unlikely Heroes

Length: 4 pages + licence

Some work their whole lives just to get by.

They may not have the opportunities that others have. They may be born to poverty, or not have the mind or aptitude to make a better living. Some work with their hands out of choice, for the joy of doing an honest day's work. But most live hard lives, and survive troubled times with nothing more than fortitude and determination.

While they are often considered the lowliest of the low, the common folk support entire economies by the work they do and the burdens they bear. With few abilities that can assist in times of trouble, they learn tenacity, endurance and resilience that few others can match.

These are The Labourers.

Fantasy literature abounds with tales of ordinary folk, lifted to the status of Hero by extraordinary events. The Unlikely Heroes are seven character classes with concepts drawn from the standard NPC classes in the DMG. They are for those exceptional people who choose not to adventure, but should fate intervene, their quality shines through.

66006.name: The Noble
66006.description:
The Noble
One of the Unlikely Heroes

Length: 5 pages + licence

There are dangers in the courts, as much as there are dangers in the life of an adventurer. But few that have the opportunity to choose a life of luxury would instead choose to put their lives on the line.

The higher classes have many advantages over the poor and middle classes. They have the time to learn to self-defense, and the money to live healthy and buy tutors in whatever arts and skills might take their fancy. Some choose to devote themselves to the courts, in the currying of favor and trading of secrets, while others devote themselves to the knighthood, to defend their land in war or their reputation in the tourney. But few, if any, seek adventure: they have others to risk their lives for them.

Sometimes, however, adventure comes calling, irrespective of station.

The upper levels of society give rise to the Nobles.

Fantasy literature abounds with tales of ordinary folk, lifted to the status of Hero by extraordinary events. The Unlikely Heroes are seven character classes with concepts drawn from the standard NPC classes in the DMG. They are for those exceptional people who choose not to adventure, but should fate intervene, their quality shines through.

66007.name: The Ultimate GM Screen II
66007.description:
Publisher Blurb:

The Ultimate GM Screen 2 is a must have for any fantasy game master. We've incorperated user feedback from our first GM screen to create this masterpiece. Bigger and sturdier than ever, this screen has two dice rolling towers (one toward the GM, one toward the players) and a quick-release disassembly design that allows you to transport or store this bad boy quickly and easily. Storage shelves in the rear are perfect for organizing the minis you need for the game, all while keeping them hidden from the players view. The screen can also be easily expanded to any length, simply by adding additional quick-release wall sections. Designed for the beginner card modeler, this set features our award winning texture graphics, full color instructions, and easy-to-build designs.

66009.name: Portals
66009.description: An abstract strategy game for two, the "Portals" board includes four "portal" spaces which allow pieces to transport between them in addition to their regular movement. Also included is a "portable portal" which can be moved (by a roll of a d4) which sometimes is to great advantage (sometimes not). Your objective: to annihilate your opponents "Guards" or capture the "Prince"... before they do the same to you.

66010.name: Reversible Gaming Tiles: Set A
66010.description:
These Reversible Gaming Tiles have been designed by Nicolas Fructus (who illustrated the Hybrid game boards) following the plans of the makers of the Cadwallon RPG.

This sets of 15 reversible tiles covers the city’s lower alleyways and exploration zones as well as indoor locations.

Outdoor tiles offer reversible locations for both day and night gaming while the indoor tiles offer up different locations on each side.

Each square measures 2.5 x 2.5 cm and each tile measures 30 x 30 cm. These tiles have been scaled for 25/28mm miniatures.

66011.name: Reversible Gaming Tiles: Set B
66011.description:
These Reversible Gaming Tiles have been designed by Nicolas Fructus (who illustrated the Hybrid game boards) following the plans of the makers of the Cadwallon RPG.

This set of 15 reversible tiles covers more of the city’s lower alleyways and exploration zones as well as indoor locations.

Outdoor tiles offer reversible locations for both day and night gaming while the indoor tiles offer up different locations on each side.

Each square measures 2.5 x 2.5 cm and each tile measures 30 x 30 cm. These tiles have been scaled for 25/28mm miniatures.

66012.name: Reversible Gaming Tiles: Set C
66012.description:
These Reversible Gaming Tiles have been designed by Nicolas Fructus (who illustrated the Hybrid game boards) following the plans of the makers of the Cadwallon RPG.

This set of 15 reversible tiles offers the city’s upper terraces and great luxurious indoor locations as well as exploration zones (square, cave, field, etc).

Outdoor tiles offer reversible locations for both day and night gaming while the indoor tiles offer up different locations on each side.

Each square measures 2.5 x 2.5 cm and each tile measures 30 x 30 cm. These tiles have been scaled for 25/28mm miniatures.

66013.name: Reversible Gaming Tiles: Set D
66013.description:
These Reversible Gaming Tiles have been designed by Nicolas Fructus (who illustrated the Hybrid game boards) following the plans of the makers of the Cadwallon RPG.

This set of 15 reversible tiles offers more of the city’s upper terraces and great luxurious indoor locations as well as exploration zones (square, cave, field, etc).

Outdoor tiles offer reversible locations for both day and night gaming while the indoor tiles offer up different locations on each side.

Each square measures 2.5 x 2.5 cm and each tile measures 30 x 30 cm. These tiles have been scaled for 25/28mm miniatures.

66014.name: The Complete Guide to Drow (Revised)
66014.description:
A revision of the original Complete Guide to Drow to update material to OGL 3.5 and change some of the art work.

From the publisher:

Drow are the most feared denizens of the underdark, and with good reason. Since the civil war that first exiled the dark elves under the earth, they have been forced to fight for survival on a daily basis. Watched over by dark gods with cruel ambitions, the drow have spent thousands of years evolving into scheming, power-hungry warlords. This book tells their story.

The Complete Guide to Drow is a stand-alone, world-neutral sourcebook covering everything you ever wanted to know about drow. It focuses on aspects of the drow that escape coverage in conventional sources. You'll learn about:
* Drow mutations and half-breeds, including the half-demon shur and half-goblin urbam.
* The secretive professions found only amongst the drow: the demon-calling Keepers, the shadowy Dark Blades, the perverse Blood Druids, the half-machine Adamantine Soldiers, and others.
* The magic, equipment, poisons, and feats of the drow.
* The subterranean society of the drow, including the horrific war machines they build from the hollowed-out shells of giant beetles.

66015.name: WTactics
66015.description:
A strategy card game with little to no luck. Several unique factions and a total of more than 60 unique units with their own traits & stats. Only 30 – 60 cards needed for a complete army
No random card draws

Based off of the Computer game "Battle for Wesnoth" this is a fantasy tactile warfare card game. Line up your troops and fight each other to the death! The goal of this project is that every player has access to all cards available. You will never be stuck purchasing thousands of cards to find a single creature, instead you just print your army!

This game is licensed under the GPL
In short, you may play the game, spread it and even sell it if you want to, but whatever you do you must always do it according to the GPL license(s).
All card art used is under GPL2 or higher, and so is the shield & swords logo.
Any other graphical material which does not depict a character or the sword and shield logo and which relates to the project is naturally copylefted under GPL3 and is available in it’s original format(s) from this site.

66016.name: Die Reise um die Welt
66016.description:
A roll and move game. You travel from circle 1 to the goal at number 50. A lot of exotic animals and vehicles can be seen at the gameboard.

Published in Nuremberg.

66017.name: Post und Reisespiel
66017.description: A roll and move game. You travel from number 1 to number 37 at the gameboard, with pictures of cities and postmen from the early 20th century. Published in Nuremberg.

66018.name: Eisenbahn-Spiel
66018.description: A roll and move game published in Nuremberg, where you travel from number 1 to 36 at the gameboard. Trains, wagons and people from the early 20th century are depicted.

66019.name: Jeu de La Laitière & du pot au lait
66019.description: A roll and move game from Nuremberg, Germany, but the text on the gameboard is written in French. "Jeu de La Laitère" can be translated as "The game of the milkmaid". At the gameboard you learn about milk when you travel from circle number 1 to 50.

66020.name: Crystalicum: Podręcznik Podstawowy
66020.description:
User Summary:

The first and yet only handbook released for Crystalicum. It includes all that players need to create their characters. Descriptions of races, rules, clues for players and game masters.
The handbook does not include full description and history of the game's world.

66022.name: Shady Gulch Revisited
66022.description:
From the website:

Set in 1876, only a week after General Custer's defeat at Little Bighorn, Shady Gulch is a growing boomtown located deep in the Black Hills of the Dakota Territory. This Coyote Trail supplement gives player gangs a base for their adventures.

Shady Gulch teeters on the brink between lawlessness and civilization. There are plenty of honest, hardworking souls trying to turn Shady Gulch into a respectable community, but there are just as many ruffians who would like to see it remain a lawless frontier town--and they usually have more guns. Into this mix ride the player characters. Will they take the side of law and order, or will they help send the town plummeting into chaos?

Includes an assortment of residents and locations from which stories can be based, plus an introductory adventure, exposing just how dangerous the town can be.

66024.name: Dragon (Issue 216 - Apr 1995)
66024.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XIX, No. 11
Issue #216
April 1995

Cover by Larry Smith.

"Hey - What the... !!!"

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

66025.name: Le Champion
66025.description: French cycling game where players have to push a ball (Carabande style) and the position of the ball then determines the next position of the rider. The game comes with six prepainted riders and a ball for each rider in the appropriate color. This game was the inspiration for the game Bisikle that was released in 2009.

66026.name: 90 Phenomena in the City of Copenhagen
66026.description:
User summary:

The subtitle of the book "Creepy plot hooks for gaming in the world's oldest monarchy" pretty much sums up this systemless book

66027.name: Dragon (Issue 217 - May 1995)
66027.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XIX, No. 12
Issue #217
May 1995

Cover by Michael Scott.

"Creative Campaigning"

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

66029.name: GamesMaster International (Issue 9 - Apr 1991)
66029.description:
From the Contents Page:

•News: Discworld sculptures and lots of RPG system/scenario/sourcebook news
•MasterPlay: The lives of the magi are investigated in Lion Rampant's Ars Magica
•MasterView: GMI's reviewers look at Knights Adventurous, Mutants of Avalon and Alien, among other things
•MasterMiniatures: Build a local pub for your miniatures, The Dragonslayer's Tavern!
•MasterGame: Part one of our viking/elf battle scenario, "Blood of our enemies"
•MasterView: Last month's book extract obviously found it's way into Mr Crump's reading room
•MasterPiece: A second extract from Michael Moorcock's latest Elric novel, "Revenge of the Rose"
•Beyond the Citadel: Steve Blease once again enters the 25mm World
•RuleMaster: FefaFl - fear , fatigue and fluster - is added to your AD&D adventures
•Cheap & Cheerful: How to RP, LRP and PBM for under £20
•MasterWayne: The low-down on the companies who attended the Sixth London PBM convention
•MasterLive: Historical re-enactment with Regia Anglorum
•MasterGame: This month it's Fantasy Warlord versus Fantasy Warrior
•Tech Talk: Battletech data and critique from Ashley Watkins
•MasterInfo: Coventions, Meets, Clubs and Contacts
•MasterMail: A particularly colourful selection of letters
•Critical Mass: More considered book appraisal from David Langford

66030.description: Each player has to complete a different puzzle consisting of 18 pieces. In total there are six puzzles depicting a scene of a Mozart opera (Don Giovanni, Requiem, the magical flute,...), each puzzle has a different color. In the beginning of the game all puzzle pieces are put in a bag. The players then take turns and move their pawn using a die. When a player lands his pawn on a space that corresponds to the color of his puzzle he may draw a puzzle piece from the bag, when he lands on a different space he may exchange a puzzle piece with an opponent. The player who finishes his puzzle first wins the game.
66030.name: Wizzle Mozart

66031.name: Dragon (Issue 218 - Jun 1995)
66031.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XX, No. 1
Issue #218
June 1995

Cover by Stephen King.

"Wing, Fire and Claw"

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

66032.name: Le leu Des Françoys et Des Espagnoles pour la Paix
66032.description:
Published* in Paris. A game about the war between France and Spain in the years 1635-1660. A gameboard with 26 oval fields.


A later edition published 1705, after the death of Du Val.

66033.name: Dragon (Issue 219 - Jul 1995)
66033.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XX, No. 2
Issue #219
July 1995

Cover by Tony Szczudlo.

"The Ring of Steel"

Bonus CD with every issue

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

66034.name: Neu erfundene Chronologische Spiel-Tafel zur Erlernung der Universal-Historia samt darzu gehörigen Reguln und deren Erklärungen
66034.description: A boardgame where you travel from Adam and Eve to the year 1718.

66035.name: Die wilden und die zahmen Tiere ein belehrendes und unterhaltendes naturhistorisches Würfelspiel
66035.description: [The wild and the domesticated animals...]. A game with money and two dice, perhaps published in Nurenberg. If you move to a domesticated animal you get money, but if you move to a wild animal you must pay. If you hit the elephant with 6 + 6 on dice you win.

66036.name: Das Stunden und halbe Stunden Uhr-Spiel zur einer Gesellschaftlichen Unterhaltung
66036.description: Published in Nuremberg. A game with two dice and money. Different times of the day are depicted at the gameboard.

66037.name: Die vier Jahreszeiten: Ein neues Gesellschaftliches Würfel- und Pfandspiel
66037.description: Published in Nuremberg. A game played with dice and money. With rules in German and French.

66038.name: Belagerungs-Spiel
66038.description: A wargame with dice published in Frankfurt a. M. A gameboard with three concentrical circles around a fort.

66039.name: Neues Frage und Antwort Spiel
66039.description: A game with questions on 24 cards in German, English and French.

66040.name: Die merkwürdigsten Männer des Jahres 1848
66040.description: Published in Germany. A game with 28 cards, dice and rules.

66041.name: Der Struwwelpeter: Unterhaltenes Gesellschafts-Spiel
66041.description: Published in Neu-Ruppin. A boardgame with 9 figures. You have five possibilities to hit the figures with two dice.

66042.name: Le Grand Voyage
66042.description:
French vintage game. Players travel around the world using destination cards that they draw each turn. Goal is to visit all continents and to do this quicker as the other players.

The game was loosely based on a tv show that was aired in the early '60 on French television.

66043.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Saddle Up! is a game in which you DON'T want to make a match. Each card has four objects, and players must place cards next to each other under one condition: a matching object or color cannot touch vertically, horizontally or diagonally! The first player who can correctly place the most cards wins the round! With multiple levels of play, the game is always different.
66043.name: Saddle Up!

boardgameintegration.66045: Scary Tales: Big Bad Wolf vs. Cinderella

66044.description:
Prince Charming vs. Hansel is the third game in the Scary Tales series of two-player games pitting common fairy tale characters against each other. Here's more about the two characters in this game from the publisher:

"Atop his noble steed, this handsome prince is every girl's dream...or is he your worst nightmare? It should be easy for Prince Charming to defeat a young boy, except that Hansel has an equally sinister sister, Gretel, and together they form an eerily unstoppable duo. It will take all of their tricks to win control of the Kingdom, but who will be victorious?"

The setting for Scary Tales is a kingdom, where a battle awaits as the king has died, leaving no heir. While the enchanted forest is feared and the castle is covered in dark clouds, corruption has affected the town and only those with the utmost abilities in Strength, Wisdom, Magic and Luck will be able to collect enough relics from the stories of long ago to prove themselves worthy of being the new leader. The challengers are sharp, indomitable, and devious - and with each match-up, it is uncertain who will win the crown.

Each character comes with its own unique ability which may be used once per game and a color coded set of dice. A set of power cards and fortune cards, a fairy card and a die associated with said fairy comprise the contents of the game. To win, a player needs to obtain seven points worth of relics, and hold on to them until the beginning of their next turn.
66044.name: Scary Tales: Prince Charming vs. Hansel

boardgameintegration.42132: Scary Tales: Little Red vs. Pinocchio

66045.description:
Big Bad Wolf vs. Cinderella is the fourth title in the Scary Tales series of two-player games pitting common fairy tale characters against each other. Here's more about the characters in this game from the publisher:

"He'll huff and puff 'till he gets his way...and if that doesn't work, maybe his great big teeth will! The Big Bad Wolf has even convinced those boarish Little Pigs to join his malevolent side. She's and over-worked, over-stressed girl on the brink who's had it up to here, plus Cinderella has her Fairy Godmother looking over her shoulder. They're both crazy for power, but which has the strongest will and resources to rule the Land?"

The setting for Scary Tales is a kingdom in which a battle awaits as the king has died, leaving no heir. While the enchanted forest is feared and the castle is covered in dark clouds, corruption has affected the town and only those with the utmost abilities in Strength, Wisdom, Magic and Luck will be able to collect enough relics from the stories of long ago to prove themselves worthy of being the new leader. The challengers are sharp, indomitable, and devious - and with each match-up, it is uncertain who will win the crown.

Each character comes with its own unique ability which may be used once per game and a color coded set of dice. A set of power cards and fortune cards, a fairy card and a die associated with said fairy, comprise the contents of the game. To win, a player needs to obtain seven points worth of relics, and hold on to them until the beginning of their next turn.
66045.name: Scary Tales: Big Bad Wolf vs. Cinderella

66046.name: N/AI
66046.description:
From the game's introduction:

N/AI is a role playing game where the characters are programs in a world-spanning internet gone horribly wrong. Something has happened, but no one can seem to remember what it was. And now sentient programs fill the digital world, and even fewer are at all interested in knowing where they came from...

The heroes of the computer network are the PCs, or player characters. The PCs are sentient programs, who try to investigate whatever it is that caused a rift between the digital and physical worlds.

66047.description:
You may never have seen horses with colors like the ones in Wild Horses, but your goal will be to round up as many of them as possible by rolling the two multi-colored dice, then grabbing the horse with the matching coat before your opponents can do so.

Twenty-one horse tiles are laid face-up on the table at the start of play, along with five tiles numbered 1-5; be the first to grab the correct horse and you score a point. If someone has grabbed this horse on an earlier turn, then you instead race to grab the lowest numbered tile on the table. The first player to do so steals this horse from its current owner. The game ends when the fifth numbered tile is taken, and whoever has the most tiles wins.

Fast Lane features the same game play as Wild Horses, but now the horses are hidden in the engines of dual-colored race cars and the horseshoes have been replaced by checkered flags.
66047.name: Fast Lane

20461.name: United States National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)

66048.name: Space Travel Hazards
66048.description:
From Rules:

The Space Travel Hazards game was developed to help reinforce knowledge of space travel and some of the potential hazards associated with space travel.

The object is to get from Earth to Mars and back along one of two pathways to accomplish a successful mission. Along the way, teams acquire Radiation Points (RPs) that are detrimental to the mission. Teams will also acquire Mission Points (MPs) that measure the success of the mission. When the game is finished, plot the total Radiation Points and Mission Points on the Tally Card to see if the team had a successful mission and determine the game winner.

Components:
- copy of game procedures and rules
- copy of game board sheet
- Astronaut game pieces, 1 per team
- Chace Cards
- Tally Card
- One 6-sided die
- Pencil
- Score Chart (graph)

66049.description:
Le Jeu du Berger (which means The Game of the Shepherd) comes with two different variants the first one is possible from the age of three and is called 'Cours, petit mouton, cours!' (Run, little sheep, run!) and is 100% luck. Here the players have to throw a die and put the sheep on the free space with the same numbers as the die roll. The child who can place all his sheep the first wins.

The second version is called 'Petit mouton, rentre à la maison! (Little sheep come home!) and this one is possible for players aged four. Here all the sheep are placed on spots with a number ranging from one to six one. Now the children roll the die and they may remove a sheep every round but the sheep may only be removed if the number that the sheep is standing on is the same as the die roll. This way the game becomes a memory game. The child who obtains the most cheep wins.
66049.name: Le Jeu du Berger

66050.description: Roule Cocotte is a game about chickens that lay eggs. First the players set up the board by putting eggs in the spaces on the board. They can put up to six eggs in one space but there are not that much eggs so some spaces will only have one or two eggs and some up to six. Then they put the wooden chicken on top of all the eggs. Now the players run a die each turn. After each die roll they can lift a chicken and take the eggs below the chicken; but they may only take it if the roll equals the amount of eggs below that chicken.
66050.name: Roule Cocotte

66051.name: Whirly Wheelers
66051.description: Cycling game produced in the UK in the 1970's. What makes this game stand out is that the riders are magentic and no dice are used for movement; instead a spinning wheel is used.

66052.description: Italian cycling game published in the 1960's. Up to five players each have a metal rider; one player acts as the bookie. Players then place wagers on the five riders who race to the finish line. The player with the most money after the agreed upon number of races is the winner.
66052.name: Corse

66054.description:
French two player game about the Tour de France. It consists of 48 tiles. 28 of them form the road, and must be played in order. The other 20 cards are landscape cards and are placed with one of their sides touching an already placed card.

The winner is the first to play the Paris card as long as he does not have any other card in his hand. Nevertheless, players take cards from the other player's hand once per turn, so the Paris card will change hands every once in a while.
66054.name: Pic-Etape

66055.name: Word Pirates! Quick Play Edition
66055.description:
Quick Play Edition. Half the time. All the fun.

Can you get to the treasure first? Roll the dice and spell a word to advance through the shark-infested waters. Roll a 4-letter word to earn the eyepatch. The first player to reach the treasure while wearing the eyepatch wins! Roll and spell your way to victory, matey! Arrgh!

211557.name: Catan: Das Duell – Sonderkarte 2016: 20 Jahre Catan, das Spiel für 2

66056.description:
The Rivals for Catan is a reimplementation of Catan Card Game.

The Rivals for Catan was released in German in September of 2010, on the 15th anniversary of the original card game. An English edition was released in the fourth quarter of 2010. The designer of the game, Klaus Teuber, has stated that he completely reworked many of the original card game's mechanics to make it easier for newcomers to play the game.

Each player portrays a prince for Catan, developing their individual provinces and competing to build a more successful province than the other. The basic mode of play is similar to the original Catan Card Game, where players expand their provinces by building settlements connected by roads. Players may also build expansions in their settlements that aid them in various ways, or upgrade their settlements to cities to allow more expansions to be built. They build these additions by using resources that they accumulate each turn, which are determined by the roll of a die. Cards are drawn on each turn to replenish the players' hands. The players may also use action cards that directly affect either their own province or their opponent's province.

The Rivals for Catan features a reduced pool of cards, without the more aggressive style of action cards found in the original Catan Card Game. Therefore, all action cards will be able to be used from the beginning of the game unlike in the original card game.

Ways to Play:
The Introductory Game focuses on the basics of the card game, featuring gameplay that is more appropriate for newcomers. This game is played to 7 victory points and includes 36 Expansion Cards in four stacks. This play style should take beginner players 25 to 30 minutes to play.

Three Theme Games add more rules, expansions, and aggressive cards. These Theme Games may be played individually or combined to play a variant called "The Duel of the Princes." Each Theme Game adds 24 Expansion and Event Cards to the cards from the Introductory Game, which are placed in two stacks separately from the cards from the Introductory Game. When playing a Theme Game, playtime should be around 45 to 60 minutes.

As with the original Catan Card Game, players can also play the Tournament Game, in which each player chooses specific cards to build their deck ahead of time from which they draw from during the game.

Theme:
The theme of The Rivals for Catan is no longer restricted only to the feudal era of the Middle Ages like the original Catan Card Game. The Introductory Game portrays the very early years of the world of Catan, while each Theme Game takes place in progressively later eras. These eras are known as "The Era of Gold," "The Era of Turmoil," and "The Era of Progress."

Belongs to the Catan Series.
66056.name: The Rivals for Catan

66057.description: Ialian cycling game from the 1950's. Comes with a board that depicts Italy with roads between cities. The players move their riders (by roling two wooden dice) on the road. The game starts in Milan; the first one to reach Rome is declared the winner.
66057.name: Giro d'Italia

66059.name: Bible Boys Card Game
66059.description: Early 20th century card game with a biblical theme.

66062.description:
Based on a tv series with the same name. The board represents different locations (the docks, police station, the apartment of Cordelia, a cemetery, ...) in Los Angeles. One player plays with the character Wolfram & Hart (the advocates of the devil). The other players play with Angel and his acolytes (Cordelia, Gunn & Wesley).

The principle of the game is to win points by fulfilling mission cards, these points are needed for the destiny track. The ultimate goal of the game is to advance the soul of Angel on the destiny track to level six (six points).
66062.name: Angel

boardgamefamily.8278: TV Series: 	Buffy the Vampire Slayer

66072.name: Cemetery
66072.description:
From the publisher's website the description of this PDF paper model kit:

Fat Dragon Games is proud to announce DRAGONSHIRE, a ground breaking new series of 3D fantasy city sets. This expansion set features the olde town cemetery complete with open graves!

This PDF includes:

Cemetery tiles
Cemetery walls and gate
3D raised platform terrain complete with dug out graves
Stand alone dug grave
Mausoleums
Sarcophagus with opening lid
Various tombstones, grave markers and more
Coffins
Dirt mounds for open graves

66073.name: Taste Taiwan: Princess
66073.description:
"Taste Taiwan" is a series of thick postcard game relevant to culture and geography in Taiwan. The first game is "Taste Taiwan: Warrior". "Princess" is the second game of this series.

By adding "Warrior", it will become a four-players game. You need to match couples of different tribes during the game or you will get minus points. Each couple will give an additional score if you finish your mission on the map board.

Can be combined with:

Taste Taiwan: Warrior

66074.name: Caverns Basic Set
66074.description:
From the publisher's website the description of this PDF paper model kit:

E-Z DUNGEONS: Caverns Basic Set offers you a modular 3D cave wall system in 30mm (1") scale for your miniature games. All models are designed with the novice card modeler in mind and feature oversized glue tabs wherever possible and simplified construction designs. All art is full color and 300 dpi resolution for maximum detail. Since the cave system is modular, you can design your cave layout to be as large as you like. Experience the E-Z DUNGEONS difference today!

This PDF includes:
1" scale floors
300 dpi full color models
Full color instruction manual
Stalagmites, Stone alter, Rope Bridge, Mining Cart, Mining track straight, Mining track curved, Mushrooms Red (3 sizes), Mushrooms Green (3 sizes), Mushrooms Tan (3 sizes), Rock steps, Cross corner, 'T' corner, 'L' corner, Cave mouth small, Cave mouth large, Cave wall 1", Cave wall 2", Cave wall 4", Cave wall 4" with skeletons, Multiple floor options including rock, lava and water, Floor tiles with monster eggs, treasure, slime and large pits.

Fully compatable with all other E-Z DUNGEONS products

66075.name: Bounty Head Bebop: Archetype
66075.description:
From the introduction:

There are 17 character types presented here which run the spectrum
of characters in Bounty Head Bebop. All these character sheets need is a name and you're ready to jam.

Contains pre-made character sheets for a Bounty Hunter, Feng Shui Master, Fixer, Gear Head, Hacker, Mercenary, Private Investigator, Professional, Psychic, Scoundrel, Shaman, Spacer, Street Doc, Ex-SSPB Agent, Ex-Syndicate Agent, Cyber Jock, and Cyber Spy.

66076.description:
In each round a different player is the auctioneer and auctions off, primarily, factories with a unique bidding mechanism. Factories bring points and produce raw materials. Building factories themselves cost money and raw materials. But they are in short supply, so you need to manage your resources well. Linked factories and other improvements bring in extra points at the end of the game.

Revision of Industria.
66076.name: Industry

66077.description:
From the box: Terry Terrier is in charge of looking after the dangerous lion, Leo. But "oh dear" - Leo has done a bunk!
Where has he gone? Terry immediately sets off to look for him. He retraces Leo’s escape route, from animal to animal asking them if they have seen the lion. But where does Leo’s track end? Who can help Terry find Leo’s hiding place?

Gameplay: The players open up the cards looking from card to card in the correct order to find the player where "Leo" has his hide-out. The fastest wins.
66077.name: Wo ist Leo?

66078.description:
The "Sechs Sonderaufträge" (Six special commissions) are part of the Abacusspiele spring catalogue 2010 and part 10 in the expansion-series "catalogue edition".

With these commissions you have the option to choose where to deliver and which craftman you take for that.

Expands:

Valdora
66078.name: Valdora: Sechs Sonderaufträge

66079.name: The Great Train Robbery Game
66079.description:
This is a game for 2 to 6 players on the now legendary 'Great Train Robbery'. On the 8th August, 1963 the travelling post office train was hijacked at Sears Crossing, Buckinghamshire, England. The train driver and co-driver were captured and the train driven a quarter of a mile to a bridge over the road. The mail vans were ransacked by the gang and the 110 mail bags were thrown down to a waiting lorry. The gang then went to Leatherslade Farm, their base for the share out. This was only 20 miles from the hold up.

Based on the actual events of the Great Train Robbery in 1963, this game is a realistic re-enactment of the chase making use of skill, judgement, initative and like life itself, a measure of luck.

boardgamehonor.21160: 2010 Charles S. Roberts Best Post-Napoleonic to Pre-World War 2 Era Board Wargame Nominee

66080.description:
The Lost Cause:
The American Civil War: 1861 - 1865 (States of Siege #4)

from the publishers website:
After the election of Abraham Lincoln in 1860, State after State in America’s “Deep South” seceded from the Union that the North felt must be preserved. In the ensuing war, brother fought brother as the Confederacy resisted with all its might for over four years in The Lost Cause.

This States of Siege solitaire game puts you in the shoes of Jefferson Davis and the Confederate High Command as the Union armies close in from five different directions. With famous Generals like Lee and Johnston leading armies for their new nation, much of the conflict also takes place on the waterways and in the halls of power of foreign governments.

Told through the use of Headline and Broadsheet Event cards, history unfolds before your eyes as you direct the Southern war effort on land, sea, the diplomatic and home fronts, in an effort to secure independence and survive as a nation. Can you organize the Confederacy and devise the plans necessary to secure victory? Can you make the best use of scarce Southern resources, allocating them at the right place and time to preserve the Confederacy? Or will relentless Union pressure make it all a Lost Cause?

Game Data:

Number of Players: 1
Ages: 14 and up
Playing Time: approx. 1 (Basic Game) to 1 1/2 hours (Advanced Game)
Complexity: 3.5 (Basic Game) or 5 (Advanced Game) on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 9 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each unit is one Union Army or Civil War Leader, and each turn is one month

Game Components:
• One 11” x 17” color Basic game map
• One 11” x 17” color Advanced game map
• One 8-page, color Basic Game Rules booklet
• One 6-page, color Advanced Game Rules booklet
• 32 color, die-cut 5/8” mounted game pieces
• 24 color, die-cut 3/4” mounted game pieces
• 48 (total) ‘Headline’ and 'Broadsheet' cards
• One 8.5” x 5.5” color player aid mat
• One page of designers notes and extensive examples of play
66080.name: The Lost Cause

66081.description:
A war game that fits in the pocket!

When pressed for time and table space and the hankering for battle hits, this is the perfect remedy - and it is portable!

Tiles represent troops and troops make up units in your army: just determine the size of the battle and create your own army from a pool of existing troops.

Each tile hits on certain rolls, and some can only melee while others can shoot. Some tiles also have special traits which can affect their whole unit or their whole army.

Armies fight in three sectors - the battlefield. The goal is to eliminate at least half the value of your opponent's army.

Pocket Battles: Elves vs. Orcs is the second game in the series of "Pocket Battles", after Pocket Battles: Celts vs. Romans.

The series is designed to have each army fully compatible with any other, so it will be possible, for example, to fight with orcs against Romans, or to have a mixed army of elves and Celts.

The basic rules of the game are fairly simple; two armies face each other in battle. The armies are split into three columns and two rows. Players must decide, at the start of the game, how many points they will give to their armies, determining how many points it will take to defeat the opponents army. (At least half of the points).

On your turn; you have to choose which faction of your army you will send off to battle! Attacks are made by using Order Tokens. If no Order Tokens are present on a unit, it costs just 1 token to issue orders to that unit. Issuing orders to the same unit in the same Battle Round would cost you the number of tokens present on the unit, plus 1. (So if there is one token on your unit, it would cost you two more tokens; if you had three, it would cost you four tokens, and so on).

After a round of battle, you may choose to redeploy you units. (Units may move from the back of the row to the front of the same row, from the back of a row to the back of another row, or from the front of a row to the front of another row). Redeployment will not cost you any Order tokens.

When one army has eliminated half of the other's original deployment value, that battle round concludes the game, and the player who has defeated the greatest total point-value of opposing units is the winner.
66081.name: Pocket Battles: Elves vs. Orcs

66082.name: Straddle County
66082.description:
From the website:

Set in Montana, just east of the Rocky Mountains and on the border between the Dominion of Canada and the United States of America in the 1870s, the towns of Bucktooth and Maple Ridge both compete and cooperate in order to survive. This Coyote Trail supplement gives player gangs a base for their adventures.

Includes an assortment of residents and locations from which stories can be based, plus an introductory adventure.

66083.name: The Chronicles of Amherth
66083.description:
From the website:

The Chronicles of Amherth is a base setting for Iron Gauntlets, providing an overview of the world and its gods, as well as detailed information for several locations, peoples, lands, and more.

66084.name: Seeds: Supers
66084.description:
From the introduction:

Seeds are story ideas, plot ideas, creature
ideas, adventure hooks, anything that can grow into an
enjoyable gaming experience. Each seed is small (only
a paragraph or two at most) and each Seed product
will be small as well (only four to five pages), but
just like their namesakes, they have great potential
when provided with the right environment.

Supers is four and a half
pages packed with adventure ideas suitable for supers gaming.

66085.description:
The second stand-alone big box Keltis game, Keltis - Das Orakel plays on a single track spiraled gameboard, on which lay differently colored stones. This re-development has new rules that open entirely new options of strategy: big leaps with the aid of golden colored clover tiles, repositioning a pawn any distance backwards with the aid of spiral tiles, thus being able to gather more wishing stones, and also the new leaf clover tiles, and Oracle tiles, which allow for more point bonuses.

A player now has the ability to move back and forth, when on specific fields. There are new bonuses, for instance when the three pawns of a player form a specific formation, or when a new figurine, the oracle lady, is moved. Because a player can choose to move any of his three pawns in a turn, the game offers more flexibility - but this also requires more planning.
66085.name: Keltis: Das Orakel

66086.name: The Magic Bag
66086.description: A turn is comprised of rolling the dice three times in an attempt to create the patterns listed in the nine rows you set up at the beginning of the game. If you complete a row, you get to draw a coin from the bag to see which treasure you’ve won! You only need match the number on the tiles, but if any of your dice match both the suit and the number, you’ll win bonus draws from the bag. If your roll does not match anything on the board, you have the option of discarding a treasure to take another turn. If you choose not to do this, the game ends and the score is tabulated.

66087.name: Dragon (Issue 220 - Aug 1995)
66087.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XX, No. 3
Issue #220
August 1995

Cover by David Horne.

"Plotting and Scheming"

Xpanded Issue!

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

66088.description:
In Q•bitz players use their special blocks to recreate patterns, claim cards and win the game.

In the first round, someone reveals a Q•bitz card (out of a deck of 100 cards), then players race to assemble their specially colored blocks in the pattern shown on that card; the first player to do so claims the card. In the second round, players must roll their blocks like dice to find the iamges that they need to recreate the pattern on the card. In the third round, all players look at the card for ten seconds to try to memorize the pattern, then they work on recreating that pattern by memory; the round ends when someone calls for it to end, with the player who successfully recreated more of the pattern than anyone else claiming the card.

After three sets of three rounds, the player who claimed the most cards wins the game.

Contents:

120 Q-bitz Cards
4 Wooden Trays
4 Sets of 16 Cubes
Rules




See also:
Q•bitz 100 Card Expansion Pack
66088.name: Q•bitz

66090.name: Dragon (Issue 221 - Sep 1995)
66090.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XX, No. 4
Issue #221
September 1995

Cover by Larry Elmore.

"Uncovering the Arcane Arts"

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

66092.name: Dragon (Issue 222 - Oct 1995)
66092.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XX, No. 5
Issue #222
October 1995

Cover by Hung Mac.

"The Many Forms of Horror"

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

66093.name: Dragon (Issue 223 - Nov 1995)

rpgissuearticle.47852: Bazaar of the Bizarre - Nine Rings to Rule Them All

66093.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XX, No. 6
Issue #223
November 1995

Cover by Roy E. Parker.

"Beasts Fell and Terrible"

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

66094.name: Neu-erfundene Historisch-Chronologische Spiel-Tafel zur Erlernung der Teutschen Reichs-Historia nach der Regierungs-Folge der Römisch-Teutschen Kayser
66094.description:
A game with 49 circles where one can see German Royals. In the middle of the gameboard one can see Charles VI (October 1685 – 20 October 1740), who was the penultimate Habsburg sovereign of the Habsburg Empire.

Second edition published 1726.

Third edition 1727.

66095.name: Roguish RPG Sample
66095.description:
User summary:

This PDF file, available for free download on this site, presents a sampler of the complete rules for the Roguish RPG. Included are the following:

A Rules Overview that explains the action resolution mechanic and character creation.
A section on Starting Equipment that gives stats for weapons and armor, and rules for combat.
The Magic section covering the rules for casting and resisting magic.
A list of beginning Spells.
Rules for Monsters.
Lair of the Cave Wyrm, a simple introductory adventure.

66097.name: Apocrypha: Myths of the World
66097.description:
Subtitle: Essential stories from mythology for inclusion in any RPG setting

From the publishers website:
Ápocrypha - Myths of the World is a collection of the greatest myths of the world, intended to be a handy inspirational book for younger GMs and players

boardgamehonor.8754: 2010 Golden Geek Best Board Game Expansion Nominee

66098.description:
There are strange things going on in your basement laboratories. They keep calling up for more barrels of quicksilver, or bits of your hair. Well it's all in the name of progress. They're looking for a way to turn lead into gold, or at least into something better than lead. That lead had just been too good of a bargain to pass up; you didn't think, where will I put all this lead, what am I going to do with this lead anyway. Well that will all be sorted out. They're also looking for a universal solvent. If they manage that one, you will take whatever they use to hold it in and build a castle out of it. A castle that can't be dissolved! Now that's progress.

Dominion: Alchemy is an expansion, and can't be played by itself; to play with it, you need Dominion a standalone expansion to Dominion (Dominion: Intrigue), or Dominion Base Cards . Those provide the Basic cards you need to play (Treasure, Victory, and Curse cards), as well as the full rules for setup and gameplay. Dominion: Alchemy can also be combined with any other Dominion expansions you have.

Part of the Dominion series.
66098.name: Dominion: Alchemy

66099.description:
The battle by Union forces to retake the planet Bey was difficult at best, a slaughter at the worst, as the resistance encountered against the robotic Morpheans proved to be more difficult than expected. After months of fighting, the Unions 15th Combined Army commanded by Marshall Jean Baptiste, managed to break the Morphean siege lines among the hills and mountains of the sprawling Blade River valley.

The Blade River valley ran for hundreds of miles, and at dozens of locations throughout it, fierce battles took place for possession of key locations. Bridges, power-plants, military training bases, and transportation docks were its lifeblood and the focal point of the fighting. The 15th CA was reinforced by Union shock troops and mechs, enabling them to push the Morpheans back and eventually out of the valley area. Mustering it's reserve units, the Morpheans responded in force, not willing to concede defeat to the inferior humans. Wave upon wave of Morphean aero-fighters and bombers swept up the river valley in a final attempt to re-secure their dominance.

The Game

Bomber Run on Blade River is a 1-8 player game where the player or players take on the role of the skeletal Morphean robots with their aero-fighters and bombers, or the defending Union force with their missile equipped infantry squads, armored walkers, anti-aero guns and counter-fighters.

Attack on Blade River Valley is a free PnP consisting of a 9 page rulebook, 4 map pages (when all are combined), and a sheet of unit counters. In addition, the player will need about 6-8 d6.

The game was designed to be played at work station or table, depending on how many of the map pieces the player/s wish to use. When all the map pieces are placed together they cover an area the size of 4 sheets of 8.5x11 paper. The simplest form of the game uses just one sheet (To be added shortly).
66099.name: Attack on Blade River Valley

66100.name: The Dragon's Lair
66100.description:
From the publisher's website:

Jonathan Roberts cartographer for Kobold Quarterly and Adventures in the Hyborian Age, presents another Fantastic Map: "The Dragon's Lair”. This multi-page PDF allows you to print out the battlemap at a 1 square=1 inch scale as a letter-format map and is also available in a printer-friendly light grayscale version. High-Resolution Jpegs of the Maps with and without grids. The file also contains two maptool campaign files set up for quick use in the 4.0 version of the world's most popular roleplaying game and its 3.5 thriving spiritual successor. Finally, all the component pieces of art that went into the construction of the maptool files are included separately. The Maptool file requires Maptool 1.3b60 or newer to work.

66101.name: The Fate of Inglemia
66101.description:
From the publisher's website:

This Strategic Campaign outline features a Very High Magic setting for Very High Level characters. It is designed to allow the characters to alter events on a world shattering level. Incorporating elements of the Elemental Dimension of Magic, Inglemia goes back to the Prime Material roots of the eternal conflict between the Jeshatan and the magic hating Knah'tan.

From the introduction:

The Fate of Inglemia is not a module. It is a product designed to give the GM a primer to establish a set of parameters for an Epic campaign involving the City State of Inglemia and its encounter with their ancient cousins, the Jeshatan of the Elemental Dimension of Magic. This product incorporates elements from the products The Elemental Dimension of Magic EDM001 through EDM013. Thematically speaking, the game is designed for characters of around PL 13, allowing them to go up in level every two sessions well into the epic levels and beyond. While it is certainly possible to use this product for a low level game, the GM also has the tools to allow his players to be movers and shakers on a primal level.

While the core strategic campaign was originally designed to have the players be agents that defend Inglemia, they could just as easily be agents bent on its destruction. Inglemia certainly is not without plenty of enemies nor is it without flaw. While it is a fantastic place, there is still rot at the core and it is primed for change; whether good or ill is up to the players…and you.

66102.name: Marlborough s'en va-t-en guerre
66102.description:
Miniatures rules for the early 18th century. Tailored for 10mm figures, but playable with other scales.

The rules contain a full set of campaign & battlefield rules for the War of the Spanish Succession. The system portrays the problem of command and the variable quality of units. The importance of keeping a reserve and reading your opponents intentions, make for a game with lots of decisions.

66103.name: Checkers III
66103.description:
"Its just like checkers but..."
The Checkers III playing board is a hexagon divided into 96 triangular playing spaces, 48 dark and 48 light. The last player left on the playing board, following a series of capturing and trapping moves similar to checkers, but based on triangular movement, is the winner.

66104.name: World Affairs
66104.description:
A game of strategy, money and people.

The object of the game is to secretly acquire the most money in your personal account so that when the game is ended you will be declared the winner. Personal money accounts are kept secret throughout the game. Each character assumes the parodic character of 80s infamy (such as Daniel Dictator, Colonel South and Ayatollah Iraney) to accomplish their indivual ends.

66105.name: The Adventures of Dick and Virginia
66105.description:
Give Your Best Advice

Dick and Virginia are a couple that suffer from a plague of sex and relationship problems. As their closest and most trusted friend, they have come to you for advice. Will your great advice help this couple keep it together through thick and thin or will an opponent swoop in with their two cents and become the couple's closest confidant? It takes critical thinking and an open mind to help this troubled couple. Find out how well your advice is received and how other players handle sex and relationship quandaries.

Directions:
Shuffle the deck and place face down. The first player draws the top card and gives advice to the fictitious couple. If another player wants to challenge the advice given, they may. The other players vote on the best advice and the winner gets the card. Each card is worth one point.

When a player collects five cards a round is complete. Depending on the number of players the amount of rounds changes. Once all rounds are complete the player with the most cards wins.

66106.name: Super Thoughts and Actions: Daredevil
66106.description:
A wild Party game that is tame enough to play at almost any adults only party, but goes the distance for even the most non-vanilla players. It is intellectually and physically challenging for both couples and singles, and is overflowing with thought provoking and sexually stimulating challenges.

Designed for all Genders and Preferences
Includes non-gender specific game play that allows for comfortable play among homosexual, bisexual, and heterosexual players. The cards have been carefully written so that all contact events can be played with your monogamous partner whether or not he or she is on your team. For non-monogamous players, there has never been a better ice breaker.

Great for Team Competition
Split the party into teams and let the battle begin. Play girls vs. the boys and find out which gender is sexually smarter and braver. Or break down the teams and go couple vs. couple to discover which couple has the best sexual relationship.

Great for Couples
Every Thought card is carefully designed to engage the party in constructive conversations regarding the most common sexual and relationship problems. Every Action card was designed to reveal the most common sexual fantasies of both men and women. Playing this game with your spouse might just stoke the flames and teach you something about your partner that you never knew before playing.

Great for Singles
From college students to retirees, anyone who admits to being a sexual being can learn something from playing this game. In one hour of playing this game, you'll learn more about your sexual compatibility with other players than you could in a solid week of blind dates.

Directions:
Divide the players into teams. Separate the cards into the four decks of "Thoughts", "Actions", "Sex Survey", and "Daredevil". The first player on the first team chooses one card from the four decks and completes the challenge. If the other team thinks they have a better answer they may challenge. Each completed card counts as one point. Daredevil card points are marked individually.

The game ends when one deck is fully depleted and each team tallies their score to determine the winner.

66107.name: Tout à Droite
66107.description: French board game about cycling. The game is a dice game, but an ambitious one, which simulates all the aspects of road cycling. As with most racing games; the player who reaches the finish line first wins.

66108.name: Swing Set
66108.description:
Get Ready to try new things.
Whether you are a woman interested in trying some girl-on-girl activities or a guy who'd like to be buried in up to his eyeballs in warm naked breasts, this game has something for you.

Play as couples or go solo
Share a hand with your partner and play the game as a couple or go it alone for maximum multiple partner possibilities.

Strategy wins the game
This game isn't just about the sex, it is also about screwing over your opponents and playing your hand smarter than the rest. Special cards can be used to double score, steal points and trade hands. Knowing how, when and with whom to fulfill sexual challenges is necessary to win the game. This game is like bridge or poker if bridge and poker were all about sex.

Directions:
The game may be played as two-person-teams or singles. Each player gets five cards. The first player chooses a card from their hand. Once the challenge is complete they score.

Any player may choose to give up their turn and draw five new cards.

The game is over when there are no more cards to draw or when one player is out of cards.

The winner is the one with the most points

66111.name: Privateers and Pirates
66111.description:
From the back of the book:

“Ahoy there me hearties!”
Privateers and Pirates is a role playing game set in the Age of Sail. Characters are the crews of pirates or privateers, out to sail the seven seas, get rich and hopefully retire to a comfortable berth.

66112.name: Monopoly: Pink Boutique Edition
66112.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Monopoly - in pink.

66113.name: The Dungeon Alphabet

rpghonor.21684: 2011 Three Castles RPG Design Award Winner

66113.description:
From the Publisher's Website:

The Dungeon Alphabet — An A-to-Z Reference for Classic Dungeon Design

Designing dungeons is as easy as A, B, C! The Dungeon Alphabet compiles twenty-six classic dungeon design elements in one place to assist the game master in creating subterranean challenges. A is for Altar, B is for Books, and C is for Caves: the Dungeon Alphabet has advice, hints, and randomized tables that bring new life to your adventures. Suitable for any rules system, the entries are accompanied by outstanding art from classic fantasy illustrators, with a foreword by noted game designer Zeb Cook.

User Comment
For the expanded edition see The Dungeon Alphabet: Expanded Third Printing.

66114.name: 4 Spiele in der Box
66114.description:
A compendium of four family games:


Primus Ludus. The aim of the game is to get one pawn of each colour (red, blue, yellow) to the center of the board. All players can move all pawns. The choice of pawn and direction is limited by two coloured dice. After rolling them, you have to move a pawn of one's colour along a line of the other's colour.
Sekundus Ludus. You roll dice to move along a path. Depending on the field you reach, you either gain or lose sticks. If you reach the finish with insufficient sticks, you have to do another round.
Tertius Ludus. An easy roll-and-move game, in which you have to get around the board with 3 of your 4 pawns. Similar to Pachisi, you may return other pawns to the start, too. The mechanic that makes the game special is the unlimited number of rolls you can make each turn. If you choose to roll another die, you can add the new score to your movement rate, but if you have bad luck, you lose everything and can't move this turn.
Quartus Ludus. A card game based on the Rock-Paper-Scissors mechanic. A joker beats rock, paper, and scissors. Every time you lose to another card, your pawn is advanced. The one who reaches the end fist, loses the game.

66116.description:
Each player receives a wooden disc and a set of task cards. All players reveal their top task card, which shows the goal that the player needs to hit with his own disc by flicking it with his thumb and finger. Throwing the disc is not allowed! Your efforts are complicated by several obstacles that lie scattered in the playing area, all of which constantly move throughout the game from being hit by snapped discs. The opponents' discs remain in the playing area as well, most likely exactly where they'll be the most disturbing.

A few spots in the arena can grant players a bonus, such as taking a gem, receiving an extra turn, or placing a barrier in the arena. Once a player completes a task, he reveals the next card and starts flicking once again. If a player has finished all eight missions and collected two gemstones of each type, he wins the game.
66116.name: Snapshot

66117.description: In addition to including components for a fifth and sixth player, this expansion includes 216 new puzzles (= 18 new cards * 2 faces * 6 possibilities per face )
66117.name: Ubongo: Die Erweiterung für 5-6 Spieler

66118.name: Nexus (Issue 18 - Jan 1988)
66118.description:
Vol. 3 No. 3

Date is best guess -- no date is given. Most material is copyright 1987 but the Star Fleet Universe section is copyright 1988.

Nexus announced that this was the last issue within the magazine. Shortly thereafter Task Force Games was sold to New World Computing.

66119.description:
Vol. 1 No. 2

Starfire
The Fourth Interstellar War by David Weber
Firepoint Five by Barton Scott
Incidents from the First Terran-Khanate War
Variations on a Theme

Tri-Cap Divisions in Warsaw Pact

Reviews
From Starships to Dragons by Bill Ferguson
Helltank by Bill Watkins
Wizard's Realm by Bill Ferguson
